summary: Christopher McCandless (Emile Hirsch), son of wealthy parents (Marcia Gay Harden, William Hurt), graduates from Emory University as a top student and athlete. However, instead of embarking on a prestigious and profitable career, he chooses to give his savings to charity, rid himself of his possessions, and set out on a journey to the Alaskan wilderness.

reviews.content: Emile Hirsch is amazing in this role. A great book turned into an even greater movie.
Oh what a movie!! absolutely brilliant!

A great movie to run away from everything and have some peace with yourself. Really impressive story, making you want to live. I really liked the cinematography, the person responsible for it, did marvelous job bringing the story to life. The acting is excellent, which I didn't except as i don't know these actors, except Kristen Stewert and Vince Vaughn. I loved the songs, that they used in this movie, especially the song - Society.

Emile Hirsch, Marcia Gay Harden, William Hurt, Vince Vaughn, Catherine Keener, Jena Malone, and Kirsten Stewart
Director and actor Sean Penn adapts the beloved novel by Jon Krakauer  
Hirsch stars as Christopher whom just recently graduated from Emory University in the early 1990s
He decides to leave his family, his possessions, and spend his whole $24,000 to charity and  to live a solitary existence in the wilderness 
He backpacks all the way to Healy, Alaska meeting a variety of people that shape who he is 
Flashbacks show how he was with his folks and his sister; some of it good but most of it bad since it involved abuse 
His sister narrates half of his journey 
Judgement, control, hypocrisy, and politicians are what Christopher is trying to understand 
He believes society is sick with being rich and material-based
Sean Penn's direction is precise, the American landscapes are gorgeous to view, Hirsch is perfect as this nomad, and it gives a proper sense of isolation but also self discovery 
This is quite the poignant character study 
We all try to live good lives even if we have to abandon the one we were brought up in to find the one that suits us most
A road film that matches the likes of 'Wild' 'Land' and 'Short History of the Long Road' 
Captures the recklessness, passion, and utter cruelty of youth 
It's ultimately a long movie and gets pretty bleak towards the end but Sean Penn proves he and Emile Hirsch work a narrative that mixes true fiction and non-fiction ingredients
Awesome film, opened a new perspective on how to live your life.

Mesmerizing, poetic, lyrical, gorgeous, and very moving, Sean Penn's new film as a director is easily one of the year's best. Emile Hirsch gives his best performance to date, playing a young man thirsty for life and all nature has to offer. It's a brilliant tour de force. Supporting players--Vince Vaughn, Catherine Keener, William Hurt, Marcia Gay Harden, and Hal Holbrook--add class and acting weight to this adventure. By the end, you will be profoundly moved by this extraordinary film. A glorious must-see American epic

It's an interesting story, well told.  Actually, we watched it in preparation for a visit to the Salton Sea and Slab City, the the free-for-all artist colony in southern California where one of the scenes took place.  It did capture some of the essence of the colony.

One could perceive the main character as genuinely trying to find his own path and figure out who he is. One could also perceive an attitude of a young man who thinks he has everything figured out but really knows nothing of life. Or you could just view him as a nut who decided to throw away wealth and privilege that a lot of people never even have a chance to access. I get wanting to leave society behind but unless you were born and raised in the wilderness, you're not just going to wander out there and survive long-term. It's pretty arrogant to think he could just figure it out as he went. I don't really care for the main character so that made this one kinda meh for me. It's a well done movie but a bit too drawn out. I also think it tries to portray this guy in a much more positive light than he probably deserved. I'm guessing they couldn't show much of a flawed character because the guy died and the family wouldn't like it. If I had seen it as a younger man, I probably would have liked it more. But watching it in my 30s, I just see a very young, naive guy who hasn't really thought this big decision through.
Feels like a slow burn at times, but the movie requires you to be patient and go on this adventure with the lead actor as he has all kinds of experiences in the wild.

Into the Wild retells the story of Chris McCandless by way of going off the book going by the same name. What I look for in films based off of historical events, I look for the performances of the actors who play the historical figures. With Into the Wild, I couldn't really make an inference as to who these people were in real life. The performances fell a little short and it felt too much like other adventure movies.
Exceptionally slow paced. It has Penn's fingerprints all over it, and I don't say that as a good thing.
intense, inspiring, absolutely impossible to describe it in few words.

Found Chris pretty unlikable, so I never sympathized with him. The idea of the journey was cool, but the reason surrounding his decision for the journey I didn't care for. Movie was just very average. The ending was not what I hoped for either.
This is a good film about life and wisdom. I'm loving the cinematography and the screenplay.
performances were okay but a little corny. needlessly long
Deeply philosophical, anti-consumerist, freedom-inspiring, emotional-wreck-threatening, and after several watches still feels like a mind-opening soul-tonic to me.

Top 3 movie for me. It draws such an emotional reaction out of me, highs and lows, this is potentially the greatest adventure movie ever made. Based on a true story, incredible performances delivered by the whole cast, scored perfectly throughout. I wish more movies like this existed, I have such a longing to feel how I feel when I watch Into The Wild.
Into the Wild is a reflective journey that studies our relationships with others and the world, enhanced by breathtaking landscapes and performances.
This movie is the best movie I have seen in a while! I think everyone should watch this. Chris's journey and all the people he meets is what makes the story amazing.

As much as it really probably isn't a 10 I really love this movie. It's probably in my top 3 and I've watched it 15 times now. It's a great story about and interesting but troubled young man. The soundtrack is excellent, the cinematography excellent, it cuts a lot out from the book but with only a 2 and a half hour run time that has to be expected. Watch the movie, its good!
A great film and it stuck with the book pretty good. If you love nature and the great outdoors,hiking this is a must see!

Freedom is just another word for nothing left to lose. Movie is well made, but it tells the story of an overly idealistic kid who goes on a journey of discover like most people but ultimately gets himself killed because reality wins over idealism. For all his philosophy, he just makes lots of very basic bad choices that shows why he gets himself killed. Ironically, the very things he complains about are the very controls that liberals like him put on things to protect nature and control you. Ironic.

You don't need to run away from your life to find freedom - just get out of your urban hell holes where you continually vote for a government to control your life and don't put your job before living. Most of us not on the east coast live in the wilds and beauty of the world but don't go off the deep end. It's funny how people idolize him and his ideas, yet call rural people that live that way today backwards and ignorant. Great saints and people through history, like St Ignatius, St Francis, and every monk that entered a monastery did the same things long before he did. But followed a set of principles and truth that changed them and the world for countless for the better. And it's that truth you're seeking - not the fake truths you make up.

Remember Watching this movie when I was in high school one of the first books I read all the way through My english teacher helped me see the beauty in story telling and writing and also the beauty of film first saw this through this movie. will always recommend along with reading the book! Cool Story and a message I will always tie in with my Experience through High school! matched my Generation.

The cinematography was visually pleasing but nothing spectacular or breathtaking, the change between the high and low saturation colour palette worked well to show emphasise his isolation but also joy of companionship which allows for the last act of the movie to feel more tragic and sympathetic. The acting from Emile Hirsch and screenplay was brilliant in the way it made Emile's desire for isolation more convincing and grounded. The movie's second act was dragged on severely and at times made the movie feel really boring and uninteresting.
One of the best movies I have ever seen!

Sean Penn's Into the Wild tells the story of Christopher McCandless (aka Alexander Supertramp), a recent college graduate who forgoes Ivy League law school to seek out what he refers to as absolute freedom by burning his money, destroying his identification and absolving himself of any responsibility to others.  Whether one agrees with McCandless' philosophy, it's an interesting and emotional story of self-discovery, wisely relying on visual imagery instead of excessive dialogue to impart its message.  Told primarily through flashbacks, the film features a strong script, some sound performances (especially by Emile Hirsch as McCandless and Hal Holbrook as an elderly man who takes McCandless under his wing), a great score and soundtrack, and some effective cinematography.  There are some pretentious directorial decisions by Penn (for example, the needless use of freeze frames during a scene in the Los Angeles segment), but overall the film is an entertaining and insightful look into the quest for meaning in life.

A true adventure seeker can relate to this movie in so many ways. Whether it is escaping a traumatic situation, or even the materialistic attitude that is consuming the world. In a sense, this is so many peoples imaginary escape plan. We just don't have the balls to really do it. This man, Christopher McCandless aka "Alexander Supertramp" shows you the challenges of actually taking on the real life consequences of running away from your problems. Although the ending is very sad, I believe that his experience can open the eyes to so many people, such as, running away from your problems or actually dealing with those issues in a healthy way. An absolute must-see.
This movie is inspirational. the soundtrack is amazing as well!!
One of the most beautiful movies I’ve ever seen

Sean Penn's "Into the Wild" is an intimate, heartbreaking and life-affirming biography drama that offers profound insights into the struggles of living in the wilderness. With his fifth feature, writer/director Sean Penn created an astonishing adaptation of Jon Krakauer's best-selling novel about an ill-fated hitchhiking nomad. Using spellbinding cinematography, Penn draws viewers into the journey of a resourceful adventurer that hitchhikes across Alaskan wilderness. Penn's decision to shoot the film using natural lighting is risky, but it works tremendously. Penn deftly uses natural lighting to convey the stark beauty and dangers posed by living in the wilderness in a style reminiscent of Chloe Zhao's "Nomadland". Penn showcases immense control over the production design, locations and music, using these elements to create an immersive cinematic experience. Penn's script is also sensational, and expertly utilizes voice-over narration to capture parental resentment experienced by children of dysfunctional families. It's hard to not admire powerful performances from the cast. Emile Hirsch delivers one of the finest performances of his career as Christopher McCandless. With mesmerizing expressions, he conveys angst, desperation and lifelong resentment of an adventurer that seeks solace in the wilderness to deal with his traumatic past. The supporting cast, which includes the scene-stealing Hal Holbrook, is also exceptional and worthy of recognition. Although "Into the Wild" is undeniably an unforgettable biographical drama, ultimately it is not a flawless film. At nearly two and half hours, it's slightly long and at times as aimless as its main character. Moreover, it builds to an abrupt conclusion that lacks satisfying resolution. Nevertheless, fans of the book will definitely enjoy "Into the Wild" and so will movie-goers seeking inspirational entertainment. As a window into an unusual way of living, hopefully it will inspire interest in the journey of an adventurer whose motto of living life to the fullest deserves to be celebrated even if his own came to an unfortunate end.

Very simply, this is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen and I do not say that lightly. Blown away by the acting, the dialogue, the story, and what the movie represents. It makes you appreciate life and how beautiful it is. Emile Hirsch deserves more credit for this role and this movie than he has gotten in his career.

Emotionally involving, beautifully told and absolutely gut wrenching, "Into the Wild" is a rich story with an outstanding meaning behind it. The fact that it was based on a true story makes so much better. Let's not forget about the amazing performance from Emile Hirsch either. Such a wonderful job by him.

This film is nearly 2 and a half hours long but somehow it manages to make it feel even longer. I found the main character rather unlikeable with their pretentious monologues and lectures on 'society' repeated verbatim from books they've read. It made it hard for me to feel any sort of connection or sympathy for him. I did enjoy some of the quieter character moments (the best part of the film was probably Hal Holbrooks performance) and the framing of the US wilderness. From the forests to the deserts to the mountains, the locations are stunning. It's a shame because I really wanted to enjoy this one, but all I can say is 'meh'.

A feature length adaptation of the Christopher McCandless story could have been pretty simplistic, painting the much-discussed adventurer as some sort of itinerant Thoreau with world as his Walden Pond, as if an Emory education and a bad home life makes you some sort of philosophical savant. Instead, Penn opted for a different approach, making McCandless into a romantically inspired, but also woefully naive and inexperienced, traveler simply trying to live life in the way that they see fit, running across other people that are doing the same in different ways. Viewers can choose to interpret him as enlightened or childish as their own perspective permits (though I lean toward the latter). Not excessively ponderous or pretentious as it could have been, and featuring the most prominent performance of Hirsch's career thus far (supported by solid supporting roles, the other half of the interactions upon which the film is built), the length is a bit unwieldy but the substance is decent; what a turn for Penn on the other side of the camera. (3/5)
A great film that shows the option of a young man for a utopian life, unfortunately when he realizes that happiness has to be shared, it's too late, very well filmed, edited and an amazing soundtrack
The book is still better. Non the less an emotional watch.

Wow! At first, I was scared that the message delivered would be a useless one that we are so bored of hearing like the one of choosing liberty instead of the comfort of our world to find himself... Blah, blah, blah. But, I was surprised because we really understand the motivations of the character and the message is different. It is the story of a guy that found his parents toxic and he thinks that being alone, in the wild, without comfort is the solution of happiness, but he later discovers that it is different. The message of this is that freedom and loneliness can give you good things, but you need people around you to be happy and that it something you explore by his writings, yes, but by the people he met during his journey. In Alaska, he was dying and suffering because he had no one to relie on and to talk to, but with Ron and the couple ( I don't remember their names) he found a new family that could have give  him this freedom and the company. In terms of cinematography, it was something to look at. The images were so good. You had these beautiful backgrounds, these focus on objects and animals and it was awesome to watch. The format too was original. It was like a book with chapter and the narrator kept changing. There was these flashbacks  of  before Alaska that helped giving some power to the film. There was also great acting by the main actor. Just to say I was as devasted as hims when he realized he had eat non-comestible plants. Visually and morally it was a punch in the face, but a punch of fruits. A really good experience. A must see.

Director Sean Penn forfeits a completely accurate biopic in order to create an encapsulating film guaranteed to spark inspiration and longing in any viewers. The soundtrack was only adequate (though by no means bad), and McCandless' relationships with his friends and family don't always reach a resolution, but ultimately the film is fantastic.

An interesting tale that was overly philosophical and poorly paced. The acting was praiseworthy, but some of the dialogue and voice overs were over the top and cringey, although perhaps the real person did enjoy quotes. The film also jumped around too much and had inconsistent pacing. The story was engaging enough, although felt a bit muddled in places. Then I correctly predicted the ending before the film began. Another limitation is that I didn't really feel for any of the characters and several seemed a bit fake (e.g. the main character was portrayed in a very positive light). However, this film did manage to put me off living in the wild due to the lack of easily accessible food. That said, I would never wander off into the wilderness as unprepared as this guy did. Finally, the cinematography, visual effects, and soundtrack were all solid. Who knows what sort of message the writers were going for.
The story isn't engaging enough but there are some heartfelt moments to be found here.
Insane story, but I couldn't feel the movie and way too much Pearl Jam.

A timeless film, filled with heart and passion. Truly a must see for an adventurous spirit and casual movie watcher alike. One of the best performances from Emile Hirsch Be sure to have a tissue box at the ready with this tear jerker.

In the end it's all a bit too laboured. Not sure what I'm meant to take from the film. Maybe something I already realised, that the essence of man's spirit is found in new experiences, as I think he says at one point. He seemed to live a short but interesting life compared to most, largely fuelled by angst, which is often the case. Just felt drowsy by the end, needed a bit more focus and a bit less whimsical music trying to carry the film through its boring parts.

A fascinating and rewarding film if you can stay with it. It can be a slog, as the main character is just not that interesting, and what he is doing is so pointless. McCandless comes out as a tragic, privileged, self obsessed bore. Any movie about an aimless person will be episodic and can lose steam. The only time McCandless is interesting is when he is actually WORKING (God forbid). The interesting people are all those around him. Hal Holbrook ‘s bit is fantastic, but it comes so far in, its a long haul getting to him. Its a little maddening when McCandless attempts to get social services, in line with those who really need it, and are not playing at poverty and ‘finding themselves’. But Hirsch is incredible all the way through. A tragic figure, but not always interesting or worth glorifying.
Hit too close to home. And made me want to live off-grid even more now.

This piece takes some liberties with the telling of Christopher McCandless's story, but in the end tells a tale that applies to all of us, that of forgiveness, love, and our relationship to nature. 

We all make mistakes, and forgiveness doesn't mean submitting yourself to someone else's will, but more in recognizing that they are just trying their best, even if that is not good enough for us. 

This movie also inspires me to become a tramp , for a bit. I am a life-long Alaskan, and I dream about warm sandy places in the way Jack London or Chris McCandless dreamed of frosty remote tundra.
I think the acting and the potrayal is wonderful.  I worry that this romaticizes what was a very intense thing.
Great book and well-made movie too. Uplifting, in spite of a tough story.
This film sticks with you. It's a gratifying journey, not always easy to watch but worth it!
Really good. Great character development.
I am not sure there is a second of this movie that has any meaning.
A master class in story telling in this adaptation from writer/Director Sean Penn.
great movie about a misguided young man. sad but based on reality
Led by a star making performance from Emile Hirsch and Sean Penn’s powerful direction. Into The Wild is a complex and poignant character study.
didn't think this would get me in the feels so much, thanks Hal Holbook & had not it been for Javier Bardem, you would've gotten the oscar easily
there are no word to describe this film
Philosophical in nature, Emotional narrative and the atmosphere buildup, but this movie is just depressing in any state
Beautiful movie. So well acted, best scenes are with Brian Deiker, that guy has serious talent!

This movie is the perfect piece to show the world the beauty of mother nature through the eyes of a brilliant direction by Sean Penn. It shows the ups and downs of the journey Christopher McCandless took backpacking across the United States, while taking the audience on an emotional journey of their own.

A deep and sobering character study about the appreciation of nature, love, relationships, and the futility of materialism and trying to impress others.  'Into The Wild' carries with it a profound sense of adventure, felt vicariously through the viewer, thanks to the OST, gorgeous cinematography and astounding landscapes throughout the movie accompanied by resonating performances and 3-dimensional characters.  It's length inevitably leads to the rare occurrence where the plot loses some steam, but thankfully the overall package is special enough to overlook that miniscule flaw.  This movie is a treat.

If I could give this a 0 star review I would. A romanticization and inaccurate portrayal of Christopher McCandless' life-changing/ life-ending journey meet 2 hours and 20 minutes of painfully boring story telling and a lack of character development, only to spend the last 10 minutes of the movie watching him slowly suffer and die. I did not laugh, I did not cry, I only cringed. The movie was so atrocious it genuinely damaged my mood.  I would do sick things to have the last 2 hours and 30 minutes of my life back.
Terrible horrible boring movie that I legit almost passed out but didn't because I'm reading the book for a class. But man this movie sucked. 2007 was a bad year for movies anyway.
must watch it. thats all.
what a story, and what a soundtrack

Into the Wild (2007)

Another unpopular opinion here, McCandless' story is both tragic and colorful even in real life. It promotes new age freedom and independence which is good actually.  A little bit of soul searching doesn't hurt anyone. However onscreen,  I'd say it's a bit too much. It sends the wrong message to the viewers especially the teens, to just give up everything they worked for so abruptly without proper planning. Just my two cents,  coming from a dog eat dog world where every pennt counts. Also the film had its moments but most of it I find it as a drag and some scenes are unnecessary.

This is one of my favorite movies. It inspired me when I was fresh out of college to appreciate nature and seek out adventure. This movie holds a special place in my heart and I hope it’s message continues to spread. Great cast. Great story. Great movie.
Even when you know what to expect, the message and story resonate. Discover yourself alone, but eventually you need good people to share your experiences with.

Terrible. Slow, weak storytelling, bad message, boring, mean representation of hippies, bad family values, out of place ending.
Sean penn and Hollywood's treatment of Alaskan wilderness and the destruction they left behind is sickening.

Not a great idea to wander into Alaska unprepared.  Books or movies aside, it is just the story of one individual who made poor decisions and got in over his head.  A true life story of what one should not do if they want to live past 24 years old.  If someone wants to die young and alone from starvation....follow this morons roadmap.

As a nature lover, I was drawn to McCandless journey into the wild.  Gorgeous scenery, and great storytelling by Sean Penn (who also directed).  Based on a true story about a young man who goes on a spiritual journey to find himself.  It takes tremendous strength to leave all your possessions,to leave everything you've ever known and just.... go.  I'm a huge fan of McCandless.
Gripping storytelling that spells out something different than we’re used to.
It has some great performances but a movie based on the story that glorifies an unprepared idiot who got himself killed, is not worth your time.

Into the Wild beautifully encapsulates McCandless' spiritual journey, with stunning US backdrops throughout. It's hard not to be inspired by the young man. Life is better shared, so share this movie with someone.

I enjoyed the movie overall. I did not mind the pacing. The overall message of non letting physical possessions get in the way of your goals is admirable.  However,  his particular journey takes me as very narcissistic and that makes me think less about his journey.  Still a  good flick in my opinion

The issue with this movie is the Director (Sean Penn). The acting is superb, It's visually beautiful, the true story captures you and morbidly lures you in. My issue is the flow of the movie, as soon as you get into it, it changes direction, it resets momentum. This is done through various music changes, flashbacks and non-linear story telling. Those can work in films if done well, memento comes to mind. However, in this case I find it takes away from the journey of the film, slowing the pace and resetting the film and characters momentum throughout.
wonderful cinematography, very good story. Great movie

A megaton stinker bomb made by one of Hollywood's greatest minds-Sean Penn.  Story about a rich privileged pain in the a** who whines incessantly about everything.  This is what it's like when Mama and Dada are super rich and don't pay enough attention to their spoiled rug rat.  Movie stinks....spoiler alert: he croaks in an abandoned bus.  He should have gone to college.
really boring, absolutely no plotline

I personally did not like this movie. Very extremely overrated, slow-paced, boring, forgettable, anti-climatic, and depressing snooze-fest. Literally the only reason I even watched this movie was because I heard Kristen Stewart was in it and I love Kristen Stewart, but she unfortunately had very little screen time in it and only showed up in the third act, but at least her acting, fake southern accent, and singing (I think I remember her singing a song while playing a guitar in this movie in one scene out in the country at night) were good, not to mention she played the guitar well too. Who ever would've guessed Kristen Stewart can act AND sing and play the guitar all well? She has such multiple talents!

 That aside, I was so disappointed by Into the Wild, it was the most overrated movie of 2007. So after Christopher McCandless graduates from college and earns his degree, he abandons all that he has earned from that and burns his own driver license, his own ID, his own social security card, and gave away all of his money to charity just so he can become a tramp living in the wild. He had over 24 thousand dollars and he gave all of it away to charity. He is not a wise person. He leaves his family behind and never sees them again.

All of that college education, graduation, hard work, money, potential, shelter, and love from his parents and sister, and he threw them all away in pursuit of his idiotic dream and unrealistic goals of becoming a homeless Gypsy living in the wilderness. He then goes by the name "Alex" after he ditched his own family and purposely got rid of his own wealth, identification, and social security. All of what he did was beyond ridiculous. How does this movie expect me to like its protagonist? How am I supposed to like, sympathize with, or relate to this character?

He meets a lot of random, friendly strangers out on the road and befriends them temporarily and spends a day or a few spending quality time and living with them and then leaves them and travels to Alaska and finds an abandoned tireless tour bus in the middle of nowhere on a grassland out in the wilderness and decides to make that abandoned tireless bus his new home and writes everything that happens in his life after college graduation and his thoughts. His sister and especially his parents really mourn him a lot and desperately want to know where he is and if he is even still alive and safe. The worried parents even call the police to investigate the disappearance of Christopher and to find him. Not once does he ever write a single letter and send it to them. That was very selfish of him to abandon his loved ones like that who love and care so much about him. 

The last stranger Christopher met and temporarily befriended was an old man. He convinced the old man to hike up on top of a mountain with him. The old man offered to let him live with him in his house, but Christopher  turned down the offer, which was a stupid decision that he soon regretted. He then goes back to the grassland where he lives to hunt for wild animals after severely starving from not eating for days, but there were no sign of animals in the area. He was so hungry and desperate to eat food that he when he found wild berries, he ate them without being cautious about the possibility of them being poisonous....which he later found out the berries he ate were poisonous after going back inside the abandoned tireless bus in which he lived in and reading in his book about wild berries and seeing the type of ones he ate earlier on one of the pages stating facts about how deadly they are and how it can affect you and the signs of you being poisoned by them, so he soon ends up slowly dying inside the bus from the poison and just right before he died, he tremendously regretted his departure from home, abandoning his family who deeply loves and mourns him, and his reckless, senseless decisions he made after graduating from college.

The main character is not someone you should look up to nor be inspired by (unless he inspires you to NEVER become a hitchhiking bum living a suicidal life outside in the wild and ditching your loved ones, giving away and getting rid all of your own money, burning your social security and ID cards, and live outside in the wilderness and travel like a Gipsy meeting random strangers on the road out in the country and temporarily befriending them, and mostly eat wild animals after hunting them to survive). He was nuts and out of his mind and ultimately paid the price for his actions and decisions in the end which cost him his life. He wasn't a bad person, just a young, dumb, overconfident, and naive person who wasn't bright and made very unwise decisions in his post-grad life. I know this movie was based on a true story, but I don't care if it was based on a true story, it doesn't make it good. I would not watch this film again, plus, I was even falling asleep a bunch of times while watching this super slow and boring movie.

How this god-awful, atrociously paced, silly, forgettable, depressing, and boring snooze-fest got a certified fresh 83% tomatometer and an 89% audience score is beyond me! This movie is criminally overrated! There are countless better movies out there that are FAR better than this, but unfortunately have lower audience scores. 

Rating: 4/10
Terrible horrible boring movie that I legit almost passed out but didn’t because I’m reading the book for a class. But man this movie sucked. 2007 was a bad year for movies anyway.

Though I enjoyed the cinematography, I found myself not enjoying this movie as much as others.

After graduating, Christopher McCandless decides to drop everything and hike to Alaska. A quarter-life crisis? He meets a lot of interesting people along the way but then dies when he eats poison berries. The end.

The voiceovers and shots were good, but I could not relate to the main character. He leaves his loved ones and family behind in pursuit of his own goals. Sounds selfish and short-sighted to me. Oh well, did make an interesting story.

2.5/5. I guess these outdoorsy hiking films don't do that much magic to me.
Great story and message
better than I expected. I thought it was just going to be one guy int the wild the whole time.
Absolutely stunning movie, never fails to bring out so many emotions. Plus a soundtrack written by Eddie Vedder makes my heart happy.
Good film inspirational yet depressing at the same time.
Good actors and a compelling story, but terribly directed and structured.  At 2.5 hours this movie is a waste of time.  Read the book, it's not that long.

Rating: 76/100, 76% Grade: B- “into The Wild” is a gut wrenching real event story. If you have read the book, you will be disappointed with this film. That’s not a negative remark on the movie, but a testament to the book. It is worth a watch
Is beautiful like the book

I have seen this film quite a few times and my opinion has varied based on my own growth in life. Into the Wild is a beautifully made motion picture and some of the segments (especially those with Hal Holbrook and those that transpire around "the magic bus" in Alaska) are powerful. Chris initially comes across as an idealistic jerk - the kind of guy who will thoughtlessly hurt others if they stand in the way of his achieving a goal. Gradually, he is revealed as being more complex. By the end of the movie, I don't know that I liked Chris, but I understood him and sympathized with him, and sometimes that's more important. Into the Wild is a long motion picture, clocking in at nearly 150 minutes. But the strength and breadth of its material earns it the extended running time. It's about many things and makes pointed comments about the ridiculousness of a society where bureaucracy and the rat race have become so cumbersome that they crush the pleasure out of living.

It's just not for me. I got as far as him dragging his kyak up the hill and turned it off. Am I the only one to think that if he were starving (or had been otherwise less privileged) he would not light his money on fire? And unlike real people living in the street he continued to magically find hitched rides in cars run on fossil fuel, a hot dog likely not plant based, and of all things a bus for shelter? Am I the only one to feel worse than bored by this lack of character? I find it dark. We so love isolation. Available to rent on Amazon Prime, Into the Wild will tear viewership into two camps, admirers and skeptics. After viewing this flick, which is based off a true story, I am a bit surprised having found myself in the latter group.  I wanted to be a believer! I wanted to be an admirer!  But, what I saw instead was someone who had a shaky childhood. I learned about someone who had to force themselves to play a part of American boy under artifice family values and wanted to see beautiful things instead.  Who wouldn't admire this guy?  As the movie progresses, however, McCandless/Supertramp has the gift of meeting all of these beautiful people who let them into their lives but time and time again he walks away from it in pursuit of something more beautiful.  McCandless/Supertramp ends up writing in one of his many books he's reading, "happiness only real when shared".   I certainly won't spoil the film's ending but I will report that at 2 hours and 28 minutes, contradictory intentions, actions, and results mix make for a mixed feelings review.

After graduating from Emory University, top student and athlete Christopher McCandless (Emile Hirsch) abandons his possessions, gives his entire $24,000 savings account to charity and hitchhikes to Alaska to live in the wilderness. Along the way, Christopher encounters a series of characters that shape his life. His journey takes him full on into the wild with a tragic outcome... 

Rotten Tomatoes consensus read: "With his sturdy cast and confident direction, Sean Penn has turned a complex work of nonfiction like Into the Wild into an accessible and poignant character study." Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times gave the film four stars out of four and described it as "spellbinding." Ebert wrote that Emile Hirsch gives a "hypnotic performance," commenting: "It is great acting, and more than acting." Ebert added, "The movie is so good partly because it means so much, I think, to its writer-director, Sean Penn." The American Film Institute listed the film as one of ten AFI Movies of the Year for 2007. National Board of Review named it one of the Top Ten Films of the Year. Into the Wild also ranks 473rd in Empire magazine's 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.

"Into The Wild" is beautifully shot by Eddie Gautier and beautifully directed by Sean Penn, it has an intriguing real and sad story and we get beautiful music from Eddie Vedder. We also get a very nice ensemble cast with Marcia Gay Harden, William Hurt, Jena Malone, Catherine Keener, Hal Holbrook, Kristen Stewart, Vince Vaughn and Zach Galifianakis. But, of course it´s Emile Hirsch that stands out as Christopher McCandless. The main focus of Christopher´s journey is to truly live life as it was meant to be with just the basic needs to survive and be completely self-sufficient, which is I reckon a nice life philosophy, but as well a difficult one if you do miss vital knowledge of how to survive in the wilderness. Still there something that doesn´t blow me away by this movie. And to be honest I can´t see Christopher McCandless being more than very naive for going into the wild so unprepared. His own fault. Though the book on McCandless' life, and the movie it spawned, were sympathetic to the whole situation, many Alaskans believe that he was foolish to embark on such a lifestyle without the appropriate skills or equipment, such as a map or compass. Alaskan Park Ranger Peter Christian has said, "When you consider McCandless from my perspective, you quickly see that what he did wasn't even particularly daring, just stupid, tragic, and inconsiderate. First off, he spent very little time learning how to actually live in the wild. He arrived at the Stampede Trail without even a map of the area. If he had a good map he could have walked out of his predicament. Essentially, Chris McCandless committed suicide." I reckon Christopher McCandless tragic outcome can be debated over and over, but essentially one should be prepared in any sort of journey in life if you ask me.

I have to say not a bad directioral debut by Sean Penn he did a great job with that being said, Emile Hersch was great and gave a great performance knowing that this was based on a true story, but the story is kind of stupid and can't believe it was actually a true story , into the wild has a very special quality to it, something which I can't quite put my finger on. With that being said for this being a nice storytelling movie and a great first time directing, I give " Into The Wild" a solid C.

Into the Wild
By:Sean Penn
	Into the wild is a story about Christopher McCandless, a young man who was on track to go to college with a scholarship but decided that's not where he wanted life to take him. So he got rid of all his official documents, donated the rest of his money, and started making his way to Alaska. He created a fake name for himself to go along his persona, Alex Supertramp. On his journey to Alaska he met many amazing and extraordinary people that helped him along the way. There was only one thing he really wanted in life though, the freedom to be alone with only him and his control on nature and his life. In the movie it was shot in such beautiful scenery it made the whole story feel more realistic and authentic. They had a lot of famous actors in this movie that i think were perfect for the roles such as Kristen Stewart and VInce Vaughn. The main actor that played Christopher McCandless isn't really famous but he did an amazing job with this movie and he seemed like the actual Christopher McCandless. The way the actor played him made him seem as deep and young and carefree as the man himself and i think that being able to have that authenticity in a character is just an amazing thing. I would recommend this movie to anyone thinking of traveling or anyone who likes to think deeply.
With great acting and an absolute killer soundtrack by Eddie Vedder, Into the Wild does something most movies can't - it makes you believe in its message.

A film with three viewpoints. The narration by the sister of "Alexander Supertramp," (the character of Christopher McCandless played by Emile Hirsch), the Supertramp himself, and the unspoken perspective of the Supertramp's parents.

The story: A disillusioned, intelligent college graduate realizes that he can not tolerate "society." As a result, he decides to dump his money, dump his car, and travel, as a tramp, losing himself by looking for himself. He heads, in a round-about-way, for Alaska where he can live alone.

Supertramp's sister provides various narrations throughout the film trying to understand why he disappeared as he did -- and gets it -- after reflecting on their family life together.

Not examined is the parental perspective -- worried and concerned -- at times fearing that Chris is dead, but not wanting to bear the fact that he wanted to disappear and they are or were at least partly to blame.

While the film is enjoyable as we follow the adventures of Chris, it is unbearable to see this story from the parent's mindset. Chris is selfish, self-centered, and immature, and never thinks of how his parents may feel not knowing whether Chris is dead or alive, suffering somewhere alone, hungry or sick.

Chris makes some mistakes living alone which eventually kills him -- wasting his life, devastating his parents and causing a great deal of sorrow for his sister.
Well directed and well acted. A sad story but inspirational.

Sean Penn is an actor who can be kindly described as 'hot-headed', and as a filmmaker he can be equally kindly described as 'mindlessly self-indulgent'. Into The Wild tells one of the most fascinating stories of the past few decades, charting the journey of a young, gifted individual who shirks all the complications and oppressions of modern life and sets out on a spiritual odyssey to discover himself and his true place in the world. Or something like this. In the hands of a less egotistical director this could have been great, an insight into the inner soul of the modern world's disillusioned young adults, but with Penn at the helm it comes across as a rich, spoiled brat running away from home because he thinks that what the cool people do. It's so full of flashy editing and unnecessarily fancy camera tricks that I started thinking I was watching 25th Hour. It would all have been so much better if we could get a closer look at our hero's true personality and learn much more about him, but with scenes constantly cutting away before they feel like they're finished, it's very difficult to empathise with him. The motivation for his trip is poorly explained and the obtrusive and grating narration is so excessive that it put Terrence Malick to shame. It is well acted and beautifully photographed, but there's only so many times you can look at a single mountain range before it becomes tiresome. I haven't read the book, but I suspect it's far better than this pretentious, long-winded and grotesquely long snooze fest.

The positives - lustrous photography, excellent performances - particularly Emile Hirsch as the questing and questioning central character, and a late appearance by the great Hal Holbrook - unfortunately can't distract from the negatives - self-indulgent direction, crammed with irritating directorial tics, and a queasy pretentiousness in the screenplay. It's a shame, because the true story is fascinating. Just think what a Werner Herzog would have made with the same source material.

Alexander Supertramp was as unusual as his chosen name. I found the story of his life interesting, and I thought Emile Hirsch did a great job of portraying his independent spirit. I could see why he was so disillusioned by the world we live in, and I liked the scenes from the early parts of his life because they gave some strong insight into why he became this man. I also appreciated the non-linear structure of the film because it breaks up some of the slower parts of the story. 

The unfortunate reality is that there are a lot of slow parts in Into the Wild. I got the idea of the journey and how he lived his life early but we continue to see it all unfold gradually. There is maybe one piece of information that is revealed that I found interesting, but otherwise there is not much that surprised or deepened the story for me. It was mostly a long road trip movie where he'd meet one group of people after another and then leave them. 

The entire film seemed to center around the ways Alexander affected the lives of others because he changed very little himself. Towards the end it seemed that might change and Alexander was going to experience some growth, maybe even have an arc. Sadly, nothing resolves. There is no satisfying finale, there is no uplifting moment to inspire hope, it just ends. I know this is a symptom of basing a film on a true story, but it left me feeling hollow. 

Delving into spoilers for a moment, I must admit Into the Wild also bothered me slightly because it did something I deeply dislike. In movies based on a true story, I hate when they try to reenact what happened as if it was factual when all the concerned parties did not survive. Like the entirety of the movie A Perfect Storm, all these scenes (at least from the Magic Bus on) are just supposition based on a few short notes scrawled in a journal. It's probably a silly pet peeve, but that has always annoyed me. I can't say I actively disliked Into the Wild as a film, because I was invested in the main character's journey, I just didn't love the overall story as it was presented.

This is an undeniably well-made film.  It looks great and has some really good performances.  There's no excuse for it's 2 1/2 hour running time as it has a tendency to hopelessly meander when it would be better to get to the point, but that's not a giant flaw.  The film does have one giant flaw though ... it's a hopelessly muddle-headed irresponsible film that glorifies a delusional, self-destructive idiot.  That's a pretty big flaw.  What's puzzling about the film is that Penn seems to understand on some level that McCandless is delusional.  McCandless rails against his parents, but as depicted in the film, they seem a bit unhappy and stodgy, but basically good people.  The film repeatedly shows you people happily living lives outside the mainstream, but refuses to acknowledge that this strongly implies that McCandless's self-destructive odyssey is hopelessly wrong-headed. Fantastic realization of the novel of the same name about Christopher McCandless, who at age 22 and disillusioned by his parent's deception about his father's polygamy, abandons his comfortable upper-class life immediately upon graduating from college to explore the country largely on foot.  He spends the first 2 years moving around the western states, taking various jobs and living off the land for weeks at a time.  He travels down the Colorado River by kayak, and, after wandering for nearly 2 years, decides to travel to Alaska to attempt to live off the land for several months.  The film is very well made, the performances, especially young Emile Hirsch, are very authentic and affecting.  Backed by an incredible soundtrack of original songs by Eddie Vedder, this is a great movie about a somewhat lost soul, but someone most people can relate to at some point in their lives, who is merely searching for what he calls "truth."  This film makes me question my own choices and lifestyle, which must say something about the power of this film.  The end is tragic, but almost necessarily so.  Would we have ever known of McCandless, aka "Alexander Supertramp," had he not perished alone in an abandoned bus in the Alaskan wild?  This is a compelling story that is, understandably, quite polarizing.  Opinions vary greatly about Alex and his journey.  One thing is undeniable - he had the courage and principles which few have at age 22 to walk into the world alone and try to discovery who he was.  Sean Penn pays the proper respect to the life of one young man who, right or wrong, chose to live a certain life instead of being told what kind of life to live, particularly by those he no longer trusted or respected.

There has been very few films that are as spellbinding as this. All the differvent film aspects along with penn's impeccable directing and the performance of a lifetime by Emile Hirshe combine in a way that is rarely ever seen making this one of the most thought provoking films I've ever seen. There wasn't a single moment I wasn't going through emotions. Whether you admire Mcandless or not isn't the point. This is the kind film that has rarely been seen before and will rarely be seen again.

*SPOILER ALERT*
*The following paragraphs spoil both the book and movie, read at your own risk"

Yin-Yang:

Yin-Yang, a very basic description opposite sides that have equal amount of each other within it. is Book versus movie is a perfect example of what a yin-yang would be. This is true with the novel and the movie Into the Wild. The movie and the novel had very different approaches on how the story takes place.The opening and ending scenes and the importance of characters are just a few pieces of evidence that separate the two kinds of story. 

"Jim Gallien had driven four miles out of Fairbanks when he spotted the hitchhiker standing in the snow beside the road, thumb raised high, shivering in the gray Alaska dawn." The novel begins in a way where they show a man named Jim Gallien providing transportation to Alex who happens to be a hitchhiker in Alaska. The overall opening chapters of the story cover the main criteria of telling the audience, where the story is taken place, and who the story is about. The book has given us more than one way of this by providing us with a map along with telling us where it is in the actual text. Adding on to this they also cover basic facts about the main character such as his name, Alex, which later tells us his full name and his real name. "He didn't appear to be very old: eighteen, maybe nineteen at most. A rifle protruded from the young man's backpack," This text tells readers an estimated age of Alex, what he had on with him and can begin to piece together how he would look like. In following chapters there is a text that says "F*uck their stupid rules" while talking indirectly to the government, this piece of evidence shows us that Alex has a strong dislike or some kind of issue as to the entirety of the government. 

The movie begins with a simple song, along with showing us two things. Firstly, a character is presented and a few scenes of a very snowy place with rugged mountains. That tells the audience not who the character is or where he is, it gives us the knowledge of one person, alone, in a very cold place. Two, they give us words on the screen with a very creative idea of using a quote from the book that I believe is shown in chapter 7, "I know walk... Into the Wild." This tells us the title and the other words that follow are just words. With no pre-existing background knowledge, the audience will not know the significance of the quote, the words on the screen or the simple fact that the words are written from Alex himself. These two things have a very distinct change from the actual book itself. 
	
As the ending scene approaches, there are several differences between the novel and the movie. The book begins with a the fact that Alex dies, whereas, in the movie, the audience has events that lead up to his death. The end of the movie is dedicated to Alex dying and how he died. Some differences include the blue sleeping bag where Alex died in, in the movie the sleeping bag was rarely shown or has no significance to the overall story. Another strange scene that was not brought up in the novel was the bear scene. Alex encounters a bear while he was dying and the bear did nothing but stand up, sat back down and walked away. The audience would have no idea what it is about or the importance of the bear. One last difference is the way Alex dies. They both had the obvious facts that Alex ate the wrong plant which is the wild sweet pea, a dangerous, inedible plant that has a side effect of starvation. In the movie it had a very quick scene as to showing us that Alex has made a mistake as to what he ate, the novel goes on for 4 pages about the plant alone. Overall the scenes had very similar outlines.

Another main evidence that was brought up is the importance of the characters ? the level of necessity. The character that created the largest difference between the movie and the story was Tracy. In the novel, Tracy was mentioned thrice in merely three paragraphs. In the book, Tracy is a seventeen-year-old girl that loved Alex: "The whole time he was in Niland, she hung around making goo-goo eyes at him, bugging me to convince him to go on walks with her. Alex was nice to her, but she was too young for him." This was the most Tracy was talked about, after this Tracy has not even brought up or show any significance. Tracy made no impact on the story, or the protagonist Alex. 

Movie Tracy, however, was something else. Tracy, in the movie, is a sixteen-year-old girl who is a country singer, that makes "goo-goo eyes" at Alex, inviting him to have sex with her ? which he declines, and they both went on a very little adventure with each other. In the movie, Tracy plays the role of Alex's love interest. There is a possible chance that the director has made Tracy a very big character due to the fact that the audience loves romance and it is almost essential to have some kind or relationship in movies. In all honesty, I felt as if the director could have taken some scenes out and the movie would still be fine. Scenes including, Tracy inviting him for sex or whatever she had in mind, the duet scene, or the adventure trip. To put all three scenes felt unnecessary.  
In summary, the status of the characters and how the story begins and finishes had clear impacts on the changes of the movie and the novel. These two subjects ties in together the concept of yin-yang and how the movie and novel Into the Wild represent that.

Into The Wild-The Drifting Soul Of Chris McCandless


If you're reading this essay then you've probably tried to read the book Into The Wild or even seen the movie. You probably know what the book is about, Alex Supertramp (Chris Mccandless) goes into the wilderness of Alaska and ends up dying, the cause of death is suspected to be poison from a plant that was wrongly digested. 
	I've seen this movie 1 time and without going through it again i can thoroughly say that the book is much better that the movie as it normally is with book to film adaptation. An example of this in the movie and book is just that the book just approaches you with a much higher level of stimulation that the movie tries so very hard to achieve but just misses. When you read the book you feel immersed in Chris's life as with the movie you feel as a spectator. Don't get me wrong the movie was great but the book was just plain better and it hurts me inside to know that somewhere in this big world there is a individual that has seen the movie but not read the book, while this may not bother them they need to read the masterpiece that is the book.When i first started this book i really didn't have much interest in it, I found myself wishing my little reading sessions would just finish quick or just not come at all. But as I continued this book I found out actually quite quickly that it was genuinely good book and I enjoyed it,I feel that if you want to read this book you just have to persevere through the hard times and eventually there will be a turning point which will result in you not wanting to put this book down. If you want to enjoy this story to its fullest extent you have to know that :happiness is only real when shared".

	Both the book and the movie are full of tons of symbolic choices some of which are a little more obvious than others and some of which are almost impossible to find unless you examine the context around it. A very large symbolic choice in this book and movie that I discovered is Chris's money. This may sound bizarre but as the story progresses Chris is constantly being given money in exchange for good and services that he's provided, he constantly believes that his hitchhiking is too easy with all them money that is given to him and he much rather having to find his next meal. When Chris burns his money I feel that this is a symbol of him leaving his past life and starting a new one from a clean slate. This to me is a very large symbol in the book because it changes everything. Another example of symbolism in the book and movie is the car that Chris drives, his Datsun. This car was seen as reliable and trustworthy to Chris when he was alive and drove it. I feel that when Chris graduated and he was offered a new car and did not take it, he did this because he knew at that time he was going to embark on this life changing journey and he wanted something that he could trust and that was a reminder of his family, this car was a symbol of all he loved in life and all he wanted to love. When I was watching the movie the symbol that really stuck out to me was Chris behavior with other people on his journey.While in both the book and the movie Chris is nice and kind to the strangers he meets, in the movie he gives off a kind of different vibe as he meets more people in the later parts of  the movie his attitude kind of changes but not in a bad way. I feel that his attitude changing is a symbol of him slowly maturing through his life. This affects the whole way he lives his life.

	This book is told in third person omniscient, this has a very impacting effect on the book and how the reader reads it. Obviously this book cannot be written in first person because well no one was there and all we have to create this story is Chris journal entries. When reading this book I felt like I was pushed into the journey that Chris took with this choice of point of view. This book was a prime choice of how the perfect choice on how to tell the story can make or break the book. While writing this essay earlier i said that I felt like I was a spectator while watching this movie and I didn't feel immersed in it, that's true but as the movie progresses you get deeper and deeper but not as into it as the book.

	My overall opinion of the movie is that it is a really good movie that moves anyone with a heart and feelings that watches i. While watching it you have to be moved inside by the rush of emotions that are perfectly conveyed the the big screen. While it lacks some aspects such as deeper lines and better acting it is honestly an amazing movie and it was transitioned well from the book.While watching the movie was good the real treat was the book. While the book starts off slow and not interesting, it quickly changes into an amazing book, the way the author describes Chris's life it just grabs you in and  you don't want to stop reading.This movie and book were overall an amazing story and I would literally recommend it to anyone who wants a slow and steady yet interesting book.

It was a good movie.  But was Chris McCandless' hatred for his father's arrogance so unbearable that he had to hurt his mother and sister THAT cruelly?  Because THAT really was cruel; and yet he is a very appealing character.  Badgering an old man to climb to the top of a mountain is the sort of silly thoughtlessness of an adolescent.  But I think he showed his manliness when he turned down sex with a beautiful, besotted young girl not just because of her age, but because he was too responsible to risk leaving behind a fatherless child.  By the time he realized he wanted a family, love, a mate, children, he was trapped by the raging river and his own starvation and weakness.

(Film: Into the Wild)
	Have you ever consider abandoning what you possess for now and return the wilderness where you will be able to feel nature at a zero distance? The answer might vary from person to person, but going to the wilderness and feeling nature would definitely be a wise option whenever you are confused. The film named "Into the Wild" directed by Sean Penn is just telling us a story about this creative and meaningful idea.
	Good movies will never be behind the times! This is what I always keep in my mind. Into the Wild is the movie that induces people to consider the human society and the world that they are living in. It goes really deep in analyzing the relationship between nature humans. As a top student who graduated from Emory University, Christopher McCandles who is the protagonist of the film firmly abandoned all of his possessions and a brilliant career for the sake of going into the Alaskan wilderness. According to what he said in the movie, what drives him to make this incredible decision is the annoying human world and society. In McCandles' point of view, the world is just a place where people are guessing, cheating, quarreling and competing with each other, and the only way to get out of all these annoying facts is to go into the wilderness that has not been interfered by human civilization. What he did in the Alaskan Wilderness is to live on his own and do everything in a primitive way, including making fire and ancient hunting and gathering lifestyle. In this film, the item that support McCandles' spiritual world and belief insisting he live in living in the wilderness is a book about the relationship between the wilderness and human beings, which acts kind of like the religious belief. All of such detailed inner demands are vividly represented in this movie, so this movie is definitely worth your precious 2 hours and 28 minutes to watch. However, the only drawback that I found in this movie is that the plot and conversations between characters are a little bit over-complicated, for words like "When you forgive, you love. And when you love, God's light shines upon you" made me extremely confused when I watched it for the first time. Therefore, please never watch this movie with your children.

A strange film. I adore Sean Penn and his films, which always reflect his anti-social masculinity and crude righteousness. But this film is a little bit too much anti-social for me to stand. I know that a lot of people love this film to death with its purist philosophy of "live simple, follow your heart, enjoy the nature, be survivalist", as represented by the protagonist Chris McCandless aka. Alex Supertramp. Strangely enough, "Mr. Supertramp" may be among the fiction characters (he was indeed a real person but viewed and depicted through the lens of John Krakauer and Sean Penn) that I ... hated most - superficial, reckless, selfish, and totally out-of-touch. Yes, he had a traumatized childhood, but is that enough for him to blame his parents, who DID care for him, DID pay all the expensive tuition at Emory for him, to eternity, and to even haunt them until (probably) their death with his sudden disappearance? Yes, he wanted to be "himself", to follow "the call of nature", then why did he recite again and again and again the works of others, who, by all means, DID call for humanism, for people to care for each other, and NOT for individuals to detach themselves from the society without considering the natural bonds between people, the love and care that others give them? It is not that I do not understand his situation or has never "tried" to live like him, but watching the film, my experiences and my conscience really call me to deplore his naive recklessness, his shallow philosophy, the way he treated other people who cared for him, who loved him... Yes, thankfully enough, the "supporting characters" in the film are very beautiful individuals, who were not at all perfect but all behaved in a very humanist way, and were all perfectly portrayed by talented actors/actresses. It was Hal Holbrook who received an Oscar nomination for his role of "the old man", but I was impressed the most with William Hurt's character with a very very touching, and revelation, scene in the end. As a road film, "Into the Wild" also has many beautiful slides of American nature, some expansively gritty, some breathtakingly imposing, and all wonderfully filmed with not a shade of sorrow or pessimism. But due to its annoying protagonist, maybe I will not watch this film again, one time is enough.

I recently had the chance to watch the movies "Into the Wild" and Werner Herzog's "Grizzly Man". Both deal with man's desire to find peace in the wilderness, and both are very worth watching.
[Warning, the following sections contain spoilers]: I first watched Into the Wild, as it was highly recommended to me. Indeed I found it to be a fantastic film with very few flaws. It centers around Christopher McCandless and follows him on his journey to be at one with nature. McCandless takes on a new persona, and ventures out leaving his loved ones behind, who have no information of where McCandless has gone. Ultimately McCandless arrives in Alaska in the wilderness, where after some misplanning meets his demise. I found the film to be more of a story about growing up and finding one's place in life, than about life in the wilderness as such. In fact, the film is explicitly structured in chapter's that are titled by various stages in life beginning with Birth and ending in Wisdom. McCandless' journey is a journey within his soul, and his search for finding "something more". 
The reason I believe that the viewer identifies with the main character is because it is such a universal feeling to want to leave the complexities of civilization behind and enter the seemingly harmonious world of nature. I think this holds especially true for those who have yet to find their place in our tumultous society, such as that tricky time when we are still finding our way into adulthood. McCandless is one of those searching for something better, and the wilderness - free of all society is the only place he believes he can find it. Along the way he meets with many strangers who become friends and strongly attached to the roaming fellow. When he leaves for his next adventure, those friends stay behind in tears. In fact, wherever McCandless goes, he leaves behind a trail of emptiness and sadness. This starts with his abandonment of his family. It's a price McCandless is willing to pay in his quest to escape the social bounds. When one of his acquaintences reminds McCandless that friends are important, he responds in disagreement, stating that happiness can be found all around us in nature. It is only at the very end, when McCandless reaches his final destination in Alaska and shortly before the tragic conclusion of the film, that he realizes that happiness is nothing if it cannot be shared with others. It is interesting to note, that his spirits take a downturn even before tragedy strikes. After he kills a large moose, McCandless finds that other animals and maggots have already gotten to the meat before he could cook it. This seems like something that he cannot unite with his harmonious vision of peaceful nature. In fact the very title, Into the Wild, suggests that McCandless is not entering a world of peace, but a wilderness where a harsh chaotic reality is there to greet him. 
But although McCandless' vision of nature is utopian, and he underestimates the dangers of wilderness, we as the viewers can't help but feel for him. The film very well visualizes his disgust with modern society in gritty scenes of L.A. night-life, where finding a place to sleep takes McCandless through the darkest and most dismal facets of the city. This is in sharp contrast to the easy-going lifestyle of camping out in the wild, where one can roam and sleep to the heart's content.
This is definitely a movie that both reminds us of our own struggle of coming of age, and our desire to have our own private island where we can be at peace. At the same time the undertones of social criticisms have us questioning in just what kind of world we choose to live in.

Undeniably, this is a beautiful looking film that will leave an impression on many, however it is entirely too one-sided and concerned with painting Christopher McCandless (AKA Alexander Supertramp, played by Emile Hirsch) as a modern-day American folk hero to provide an objective view on his travels or motivations.

The subplot introduced whereby Christopher's sister Carine (Jen Malone) tries to make sense of Christopher's disappearance reveals a lot of dark secrets from Christopher's youth, that might explain why he wanted to leave and perhaps never return, never resonates with what we see of the young man's adventures: Hirsch plays McCandless as one-note, always happy and philosophising, with nary a hint of any underlying angst or family issues. The two strands never coalesce, in spite of some ham-fisted eulogising shoe-horned in to an overly-sentimental climax, and an arguably more compelling investigation into what this man's motivations might have been is raised by Penn and then completed ignored in favour of propaganda.

These complaints (and a few others) aside, there is still no denying that Into The Wild is a beautiful and indelible film. The impression it leaves, however, is down to whether you question or accept what is present herein.

Sean Penn's new movie Into the Wild arrives on the wave of a well-regarded novel about a college graduate who decides that the anger and violence in civilized society is too much to handle and commences a journey through nature in order to truly live life as it was meant to be. This film is a wonderful glimpse into the life of a kid, wise beyond his years, and the bonds that he creates with people along the way. A victim of excess in wealth and a shortage of love, Christopher McCandless hid inside his mind behind knowledge and philosophy, building up his intellectual strength, as well as the physical, in order to complete his trek, ultimately leading him to Alaska. Penn never falls into the trap of showing too much heartbreak on the side of McCandless's parents, because he doesn't want the audience to second-guess the decision he made. There is no debate to be had here, our protagonist has no alternative but to get out and live off the land. Only being completely self-sufficient can he grasp a meaning for his life and one day perhaps go back with that knowledge fully learned.

Emile Hirsch is absolutely brilliant with his good-natured attitude and affable charm. His character believes that human contact is not necessary for happiness and never seeks out relationships. However, his character is so likable that they find him and latch on, not to change his mind, but to experience his level of being and hopefully learn something from him and help enlarge his vocabulary on life. The people he meets help him to fully grasp the decision of life in the wild and be able to survive it. Never coming off condescendingly to those he crosses paths with, Hirsch always holds a smile on his face. One scene, where he meets up with a couple of people from Europe, proves how contagious a clear outlook on life without the troubles of societal restraints can be. These three kids have a blast, if only for a few minutes-with Hirsch being chased by the police for rafting with no license-and it makes one wonder if maybe we all should take a journey into nature and feel the freedom and full warmth of heart that a lack of stress to succeed in the business world can give.

All the supporting players are magnificent at helping show the side to McCandless that Penn needs on display to succeed. Hal Holbrook, Brian Dierker, and Catherine Keener are by far the best of these side characters with Vince Vaughn and Kirsten Stewart adding some charm too. Dierker, Keener, and Stewart play hippie, flower-child type roles and allow Hirsch to show off how modest and unselfish he is. This is the family he deserved to have from birth and he is the son they wished their lives had earned them. At their best, all four together give some of the most emotionally charged moments in the film. Holbrook, on-the-other-hand, helps give insight into the philosophy that Hirsch needs to live with in order to survive the loneliness, looking him in the face, to come in Alaska. It is truly fascinating to see how every person adds something to his overall experience and to the tools he needs.

Hirsch deserves a lot of credit because he truly outshines the film itself with his dedication and sacrifice to the role. The length of time needed to allow him the ability to lose the weight necessary for a main plot point in the movie is crazy. If the time wasn't that long and Hirsch did it all rapidly, I'm even more impressed. With all that, there are many instances free of dialogue that he needs to carry with body language and actions alone. True, much of this is enhanced by a wonderful soundtrack from Eddie Vedder, but evenso it is a remarkable performance. Kudos to Sean Penn for a gorgeous filming job also. He captures the countryside with grace, while infusing many moments of visual style by slow-motioning glimpses, knowing when to show the family left behind, utilizing informative and essential voice-over, and even breaking the fourth wall. When Hirsch first looks into the camera, at the audience, it does not seem unnatural in the slightest, but instead an amazing link for the viewers to take a look into his soul like those that crossed his path have. McCandless is so pure that it almost feels like glimpsing the calm protectiveness of God.

McCandless' much-debated death is not factually presented here (rather based on the original hypothesis featured in Jon Krakauer's 1996 book), but is a dramatic, confronting and affecting exercise in filmmaking and acting.

Into the Wild was originally a novel by Jon Krakauer, a novel that has had a profound impact on my life. It chronicles the true story of a young man named Chris McCandless who leaves his family and former life behind after graduating from college to pursue a life on the road. An adherent of Henry David Thoreau and Leo Tolstoy, he leaves behind his possessions and lives as close to nature as possible. He even adopts a new name, Alexander Supertramp, to signify how completely he is leaving behind his former life. I've always identified with McCandless, being an idolizer of Thoreau's ideals myself. Seeing a screen adaptation of this novel was a deeply moving experience for me. It is an excellent translation of the novel to the screen.
       There isn't really much of a story line to this film. McCandless tramps across America, meeting several people who befriend and aid him. Eventually, he reaches Alaska, where the story ends. Its not the events that occur in the film that make this a great movie, it is the ideals set forth in the film that do. McCandless' condemnation of modern, materialistic living, his search for joy in every aspect of life, his deep connection with nature, are what make this film so extraordinary.
       Emile Hirsch delivers an astonishing performance as Chris. This performance really can't be explained. It must be seen to be truly appreciated. Hirsch becomes Chris. It is mesmerizing.
       In Walt Whitman's Song of the Open Road he says, "I swear to you there are divine things more beautiful than words can tell." That is how I feel writing about this movie. Watch it. Revel in the extraordinary journey of McCanless. Be amazed.

       A note: It would be beneficial for the viewer to read the novel first and I highly encourage you to do so. The novel more fully explores Chris's motives for doing what he does and makes the movie a better experience.
